data.title: 45 Best Pop Songs of the 21st Century
data.meta_description: Here are the best pop songs of the 21st century, from pop legends Kelis and MIA to 2023 tunes from Madonna and Dua Lipa.
data.text:
Don't listen to what Radiohead said: pop will never, ever die. It's 2023, and banging new pop songs are getting released every week. Kylie's 2023 anthem â€˜Padam Padamâ€™ has even made it to our top spot on this list, with its euphoric electropop vibes, and Dua Lipa's â€˜Barbieâ€™ tune â€˜Dance the Nightâ€™ is up there with the greats.

But of course, the 21st century is a long one, and you've got to make space for the classics too. There are fabulous pop songs from every era, and they all deserve a spot on our ultimate list. Here you'll find everyone from Outkast to MIA, and from Kelis to Harry Styles. The only criteria? It has to be feel good, and it has to make you want to get up and dance. All of these tunes do just that, and then some. Read on for the best pop songs ever made.

Contributors: India Lawrence, Andrzej Lukowski, James Manning, Ella Doyle, Nick Levine, Amy Smith, Alyssa Ammirato, Jess Phillips, Matthew Singer.

RECOMMENDED:

ðŸŽ‰ The best party songs ever made

ðŸŽ¸ The best classic rock songs

ðŸŽ¤ The best karaoke songs

ðŸŽ¶ The best â€™80s songs

ðŸŽµ The best â€™90s songs

1. â€˜Padam Padamâ€™ by Kylie Minogue

Kylieâ€™s still go it. After hearing this song approximately one million times in London during summer 2023, â€˜Padam Padamâ€™ has solidified itself in the very top tier of songs that are surefire to induce dancefloor euphoria. â€˜We donâ€™t need to use our words / I just want to see whatâ€™s underneath that t-shirt,â€™ Minogue teases in this sexy and frivolous electropop track about lust at first sight. And we love to see a 55-year-old pop star in her prime, celebrating her sexuality. Go off!

2. â€˜Umbrellaâ€™ by Rihanna featuring Jay-Z

Rihanna is the queen of pop bangers, but nothing has quite compared to â€˜Umbrellaâ€™ since it was released (we know, that's a controversial statement). â€˜Umbrellaâ€™ not only introduced the world at large to one of pop's biggest stars, but it also ushered in a pop-culture dynasty, with fellow mogul Jay-Z on board to co-sign. As soon as you hear the intro (and the â€˜uh-huh, uh-huh), you know you're in for a ride, but nothing can prepare you for the chorus after the bridge. If you're not screaming it at the top of your lungs, you're doing it wrong. Long live Queen Ri.

Advertising

3. â€˜Toxicâ€™ by Britney Spears

On this iconic 2003 single, Britney transforms into a stealthy femme fatale, her voice soaring and dipping over a deranged synth-string arrangement that wouldnâ€™t seem out of place in a Hitchcock film. Even now, nearly two decades later and with the #FreeBritney movement having highlighted the horrific treatment sheâ€™s had to endure, itâ€™s a disorienting stunner of a pop masterpiece.

4. â€˜Hits Differentâ€™ by Taylor Swift

Between saving fans from jobsworth security guards on the Eras Tour, re-recording her third studio album, Speak Now (Taylorâ€™s Version), and dating a semi-problematic frontman, Taylor Swift has found time to release three new songs as part of â€˜Midnights (Til Dawn Edition).â€™ â€˜Hits Differentâ€™, from 2022, is the danceable heartbreak hit, detailing her breakup from boyfriend of six years, Joe Alwyn (sob). Itâ€™s both melodramatic and teenage angsty, stuffed with slogan tee lines like â€˜I pictured you with other girls in love, then threw up on the streetâ€™ as she skims over past relationships. But the lyric â€˜you were the one that I loved, don't need another metaphorâ€™ has the emotional maturity of a woman secure in her own truth, levelheadedly accepting the end without blame or malice. Itâ€™s melancholy, nostalgic, upbeat and a relatable tale for recently single gals. Queen Tay strikes the bullseye again.

Jessica Phillips

Social Media Editor

Advertising

5. â€˜Rolling in the Deepâ€™ by Adele

The London diva exploded to international fame with this stunning tune, released when she was just 21 years old â€” though her voice carries the expertise of a woman decades older. High-reaching vocals, a bone-chilling opening note andthe ever-relatable subject matter of tarnished love scored Adele two Grammy Awards as fans around the world cried to the breakup anthem.

6. â€˜Tornâ€™ by Natalie Imbruglia

Beth from â€˜Neighboursâ€™ covers a four-year-old grunge song first recorded in Danish: it really doesnâ€™t sound like a recipe for pure pop gold. But a breezy guitar-strumming arrangement and Natâ€™s utterly sincere vocals catapulted â€˜Tornâ€™ into all-time classic status, transfiguring the Ednaswap originalâ€™s sludgy angst into a complex and grown-up sketch of post-breakup breakdown. Feel your heart leap when that soaring guitar outro hits.

James Manning

Content Director, EMEA

Advertising

7. â€˜Dance the Nightâ€™ by Dua Lipa

Pop queen Dua has been blessing us with bangers since 2015, but her 2023 release Dance the Night might be one of the most hyped yet (hint: itâ€™s because it was in Barbie). Dua had a cameo in the new film, so itâ€™s safe to say the song became a pretty big deal. But Barbie or no Barbie, this is an easy, breezy pop hit that opens with some seriously sweet violin and is reminiscent of disco at points, but still rings with Lipaâ€™s iconic sound. Ella Doyle

8. â€˜Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)â€™ by BeyoncÃ©

Sure, we could have picked â€˜Crazy in Loveâ€™ instead, but thereâ€™s something even more transcendent about Queen Beyâ€™s ode to flying solo. The super-sleek beats and naggingly catchy vocal hooks combine to create such an instant classic that even Liza Minnelli has covered it. And pretty well, too.

Advertising

9. â€˜Rehabâ€™ by Amy Winehouse

â€˜Rehabâ€™ was always a great pop song, but following Amy Winehouseâ€™s tragic death in 2011, itâ€™s acquired a hauntingly poignant quality, too. Mark Ronsonâ€™s doo-wop-inspired production swathes the singerâ€™s soulful voice like a cashmere blanket, creating a timeless ode to defiance that hits hard with every last â€˜no, no, noâ€™. Rest in Power, Amy.

10. â€˜Dancing on My Ownâ€™ by Robyn

Countless songs are about dancing the pain away, but few achieve the emotional catharsis of the Swedish singerâ€™s all-time bittersweet banger. The irony, of course, is that no one ever dances alone to â€˜Dancing On My Ownâ€™ - the floor is always going to fill the second those opening synth strobes hit, and the whole joint will unite for the skyscraping chorus. But donâ€™t be surprised to see a few misty eyes when the lights go up.

Advertising

11. â€˜Hey Ya!â€™ by Outkast

Outkast ATLien AndrÃ© 3000 took a break from changing the rap game for this unexpectedly sunny '60s throwback that sees the superstar hit pause as an emcee to play bandleader. In a discography of unexpected twists and turns, it was a move nobody could have seen coming from the â€˜Ms. Jacksonâ€™ legend, and further proof that AndrÃ© can do pretty much anything. Truly cooler than a polar bear's toenails.

12. â€˜Party in the U.S.A.â€™ by Miley Cyrus

This song hails from a different era of Cyrus, before she transformed into a Robin Thicke-humping sexpot with a Gene Simmons tongue. This midway point between modern Miley and Hannah Montana is a ray of sing-along sunshine. Anyone who claims not to know the words (or belt them out and roll the windows down whenever the songâ€™s on the radio) cannot be trusted.

Advertising

13. â€˜Hollaback Girlâ€™ by Gwen Stefani

Rumour has it that this 2004 chart-topper was aimed at Courtney Love, who had apparently dismissed Stefani as a â€˜cheerleaderâ€™ in an interview. Either way, thereâ€™s no denying that the minimal beat supplied by the Neptunes still hits hard, or that Stefani sounds great spelling out â€˜B-A-N-A-N-A-Sâ€™ over it.

14. â€˜Hips Don't Lieâ€™ by Shakira featuring Wyclef Jean

Topping her global breakthrough hit â€˜Whenever, Whereverâ€™ was always going to be a tall order, but Shakira managed it in 2005 with this colossal reggaeton bop. More than 15 years later, â€˜Hips Don't Lieâ€™ still gets everyone on the dance floor, though not everyone manages to echo Wyclefâ€™s â€˜Shakira, Shakiraâ€™ shoutout quite on the beat.

Advertising

15. â€˜SexyBackâ€™ by Justin Timberlake

â€˜For whoever is claiming that they are bringing sexy back, sexy never left!â€™ certified Sexy MF Prince quipped when JT started blazing up the charts with this Timbaland-produced all-timer fusing raw sexuality and funk bonafides. Prince was, of course, right. But as far as a career reinvention goes, Timberlake's is one for the books: â€˜SexyBackâ€™ doesn't so much close the door on the singer's ramen-haired boy-band chapter as burn it to the ground.

16. â€˜Uptown Funkâ€™ by Mark Ronson and Bruno Mars

Mark Ronson and Bruno Mars really struck gold with this Michelle Pfeiffer-namechecking throwback jam. Not only did â€˜Uptown Funkâ€™ clean up at the 2015 Grammys, even winning Record of the Year, but it became the third most-watched video ever on YouTube. Wedding reception dance floors will never be the same again.

Advertising

17. â€˜Call Me Maybeâ€™ by Carly Rae Jepsen

This song made 2012 the year of the cheesy pickup line after Justin Bieber and Selena Gomezâ€™s lip-sync sesh catapulted this tune onto the radio. Jepson hasnâ€™t had another equally huge hit since, but she has facilitated millions of hasty flirtations and phone number solicitations. Thanks, Carly Rae!

18. â€˜Poker Faceâ€™ by Lady Gaga

Gaga's entire catalogue is a celebration of individuality, allyship and letting your freak flag fly. â€˜Poker Faceâ€™ remains a staple of the pop pantheon thanks to its grimy-glam melodies and bombastic vocal breaks. Plus, Gaga managed to sneak the line â€˜f*ck her faceâ€™ onto radio for yeears without anyone noticing. If thatâ€™s not the mark of a queen, nothing is.

Advertising

19. â€˜Paper Planesâ€™ by MIA

Maya Arulpragasam might have stayed as a pure cult artist, jobbing away on the critically acclaimed fringes with her wildly eclectic stew of electronics, world influences and controversial opinions. However, she only had to go and make one genuine pop masterpiece, didnâ€™t she? Based around an interpolation of The Clashâ€™s â€˜Straight To Hellâ€™, â€˜Paper Planesâ€™s languid, irresistibly catchy backing weaves a semi-satirical tale of MIAâ€™s difficulties in getting a US visa. A sleeper hit, its prominent placing in the soundtracks to â€˜Pineapple Expressâ€™ and â€˜Slumdog Milliomnaireâ€™ saw it finally crack the charts, big time.

20. â€˜Starshipsâ€™ by Nicki Minaj

The hip-hop queenâ€™s most sugary, hyperactive and kaleidoscopic song is a titanic explosion of energy. Transitioning from a catchy hook to rapid-fire rap, via saccharine melodies and undulating electronica, it really does make you feel elevated regardless of whether youâ€™re actually â€˜higher than a motherfuc*erâ€™. Pure chaos, and an absolute blast.

Advertising

21. â€˜Royalsâ€™ by Lorde

The small-town New Zealand export was only 15 when she penned this international mega-hit deflating hip-hopâ€™s obsession with bling and braggadocio. Itâ€™s not the kind of thing that happens a lot in pop music, which makes the incredibly sparse, intricately layered, ultra-classy â€˜Royalsâ€™ even more of a treasure. â€˜Let me be your ruler,â€™ sang Lorde. â€˜Yes please,â€™ replied millions.

22. â€˜Bad Guyâ€™ by Billie Eilish

Like fellow pop royal Lorde, Eilish was just a teen when she dropped this subversive ode to bad behaviour. Brother Finneasâ€™ thumping beats and spooky hooks hold the whole thing together, but it's Eilishâ€™s smoky voice â€” bounding between deeply unsettling and sprightly â€” that sells the whole ghoulish affair. The result cemented her as the antithesis of a squeaky-clean pop star and scared the ever-loving shit out of her target audienceâ€™s parentss.

Advertising

23. â€˜Good as Hellâ€™ by Lizzo

An instant feel-great classic, Lizzoâ€™s â€˜Good as Hellâ€™ is the very definition of infectious thanks to its instantly recognisable piano beat, Lizzoâ€™s forceful-yet-playful cadence and a pervasive, universal ability to make anybody within earshot strut for its entire runtime.

24. â€˜Get Luckyâ€™ by Daft Punk featuring Pharrell

After floating around the cosmos in a pyramid-shaped spaceship for eight years, the French-house robots returned to Earth to dropâ€¦a throwback disco album? Reactions to Random Access Memories remain mixed, but its lead single is an unassailable jam, bringing together Pharrellâ€™s falsetto vocals and Chic demigod Nile Rodgersâ€™ distinctively funky guitar for a collision of past and future that grooves all night â€˜til the sun.

Advertising

25. â€˜Dynamiteâ€™ by BTS

The K-Pop supergroup has taken over the world, and there seems to be no sign of them slowing down. You either get on the train or get run over by it. Luckily, the bandâ€™s long-awaited English-language debut delivered, hijacking airwaves and talk shows with its perfectly calibrated bubblegum. Twenty years after NSYNC said â€˜bye bye byeâ€™, a new kingdom pop has raised its flag.

26. â€˜Adore Youâ€™ by Harry Styles

The former One Direction star's solo career has gone many unexpected places, no more so than on his recent, genre-hopping album â€˜Fine Lineâ€™. And while the funky â€˜Watermelon Sugarâ€™ brings the double entendres, â€˜Adore Youâ€™ is Styles at his most endearing and infectious: a slow-paced, driving, and vocally lovely instant classic. As a bonus, the surreal video finds the hearthrob enamoured with a giant fish... and it's everything.

Advertising

27. â€˜No Tears Left to Cryâ€™ by Ariana Grande

Arianaâ€™s evolution from sugar-sweet pop princess to her generationâ€™s foremost chronicler of the Kama Sutra has been astonishing, if a little much for some pearl-clutching early fans. She hit a universally appealing sweet spot with this 2018 bop, which ascends to the stratosphere with each repetition of â€˜pickinâ€™ it upâ€™. As her voice swoops and soars, it seems to confirm the arrival of a global superstar whose talent stands taller than even her highest ponytail.

28. â€˜Drivers Licenseâ€™ by Olivia Rodrigo

Pop's current heir apparent exploded onto the scene with this universally gripping, emotionally ripe tale of teenage yearning: a piano ballad with a forlorn melody, a driving backbeat and some of the most bracing vocals in recent pop. Rodrigo wears her love of Taylor Swift on her sleeve, so much so that fans call her the second coming while haters cry ripoff. For what itâ€™s worth, Swift (unlike Courtney Love) is a fanâ€¦ and rumours continue to swirl about an upcoming collaboration that could rock the pop world to its core.

Advertising

29. â€˜Sorryâ€™ by Justin Bieber

Taking a hiatus from making music to focus on growing up a little, the Biebs came back with â€˜Purposeâ€™ in 2015. â€˜Sorryâ€™, the second single from the album, was mixed by Skrillex â€” and in a stroke of genius and surprising modesty, he excluded himself from the music video and focused on an oft-imitated squad of dancers instead.

30. â€˜Titaniumâ€™ by David Guetta featuring Sia

Empowering, escalating and full of raw power, â€˜Titaniumâ€™ is what happens when one of the worldâ€™s best producers meets one of its most prolific pop writers. Namely: fireworks. Sia may have found further success swinging from chandeliers, but as a vocalist she has never been more explosive than here.

Advertising

31. â€˜Happyâ€™ by Pharrell Williams

Only somebody as tuned-in to the pop landscape as Williams could take a throwaway track from a Minions movie and turn it into an enduring ode to being in a great mood. Think of it like this: Three years after â€˜Happyâ€™, Justin Timberlake tried to replicate its good vibes for the Trolls soundtrack. But, we're not talking about Justin Timberlake here. Such is the power of a Neptune using his powers for good.

32. â€˜Hotline Blingâ€™ by Drake

Take away the mountain of memes, ignore Drakeâ€™s beautiful dad dancing and this pop song would still be a winner for the ages. That delicate, trickling calypso beat effortlessly shrugs off the lover who never calls, transforming a classic tale of ghosting into an eminently danceable revenge song that everyone â€“ ex included â€“ would struggle to resist. No wonder it was literally inescapable for the whole of summer â€˜15.

Advertising

33. â€˜Milkshakeâ€™ by Kelis

Kelisâ€™s brag that her â€˜milkshake brings all the boys to the yardâ€™ has given this magnetic dancefloor anthem legs. Driven by an all-time great Neptunes beat, itâ€™s a pop-R&B bop every bit as box-fresh as when it dropped (as part of Kelisâ€™s excellent â€˜Tastyâ€™ album) in 2003.

34. â€˜Hung Upâ€™ by Madonna

Never, ever write off Madonna: perhaps her greatest defiance of conventions (of many) is that sheâ€™s continued to have genuine pop hits way into middle age. â€˜Hung Upâ€™ isnâ€™t even the only candidate for a best twenty-first-century pop song from Madonna, but it is the best, a magnificent disco banger turbocharged by the inspired interpolation of Abbaâ€™s â€˜Gimme! Gimme! Gimme! (A Man After Midnight)â€™.

Advertising

35. â€˜Despacitoâ€™ by Luis Fonsi and Daddy Yankee

Nearly inescapable between 2017 and 2018, â€˜Despacitoâ€™ is one of those songs that became so prevalent that people mistook its ubiquity for annoyance. A few years on, however, the ultra-smooth collision of Latin pop and reggaeton has aged remarkably well from song-of-the-summer status to certifiable classic.

36. â€˜Bootyliciousâ€™ by Destiny's Child

Frankly, weâ€™re still not sure what â€˜this jellyâ€™ is, and 20 years on we're still not sure we're ready for it. But what is certain is that the legendary girl group, facing the inevitablility of BeyoncÃ©â€™s solo ascendance, fired off one last barn-burner to usher in the '00s, and the dance floor was never the same.

Advertising

37. â€˜Fireworkâ€™ by Katy Perry

Part dance floor anthem, part inspirational power song, â€˜Fireworkâ€™ was Katy Perryâ€™s third release from 2010's â€˜Teenage Dreamâ€™ album and a huge elevation point in her career. It won MTVâ€™s 2011 VMA for Video of the Year and earned two Grammy nominations, and all the hoopla around Seth Rogen and James Francoâ€™s The Interview gave it another boost of publicity in 2014.

38. â€˜Work Itâ€™ by Missy Elliott

Missyâ€™s avante-garde approach to pop-infused hip-hop is at its best when she has certified master Timbaland at her side, and no pairing hits with the same mix of chaotic glee, weirdness and pop sensibility as â€˜Work Itâ€™. Only an artist as nimble as Missy could take a jumbled mass of backwards-masked syllables and make it one the eraâ€™s most recognisable choruses... and one of karaoke nightâ€™s biggest flexes.

Advertising

39. â€˜Canâ€™t Get You Out of My Headâ€™ by Kylie Minogue

A young Kylie Minogue scored numerous global hits in the late â€˜80s with a succession of cheesy tunes that capitalised on the fame bought on by her role in the Australian soap opera â€˜Neighboursâ€™. But it arguably took until 2001 for her to finally put out a bona fide masterpiece: â€˜Canâ€™t Get You Out of My Headâ€™ is sultry, disco-pop perfection, with its â€˜la la laâ€™ hook destined to stay lodged in our heads for the rest of the century and beyond.

40. â€˜American Boyâ€™ by Estelle featuring Kanye West

Both sides of the pond get some swagger on this pulsing throwback track occupying the space between disco, hip hop and pop. Estelleâ€™s cockney-infused vocals provide the perfect antidote to Kanyeâ€™s braggadocioâ€¦ no small task, given that the guy is 5-foot-7 of pure ego. Even â€˜Ye takes a back seat to Estelle when sheâ€™s firing on all cylinders (with an assist by wil.i.am and John Legend on writing duties, natch).

Advertising

41. â€˜Since U Been Goneâ€™ by Kelly Clarkson

Simon Cowell may have made Kelly Clarkson a celebrity, but â€˜Since U Been Goneâ€™ made her a star. Outside American Idol viewers and the two people who watched From Justin to Kelly, this was the worldâ€™s true introduction to Clarkston's mighty lung capacity, and a high point for the early-noughties pop-rock explosion. The gleeful break-up anthem comes off like a glorious cross between Avril Lavigne and â€˜I Will Surviveâ€™. Fittingly in the flat circle of the pop world, it's now regularly butchered on talent shows worldwide.

42. â€˜Let Me Blow Ya Mindâ€™ by Eve featuring Gwen Stefani

A slinky, swaggering slow jam that meets at the intersection of hip-hop and pop, Eveâ€™s biggest hit is essentially a four-minute not-so-humblebrag about career success. Itâ€™s the kind of thing that male rappers do all the time but somehow draws blowback when a woman does it (see also: â€˜WAPâ€™). Let the haters feign their dismay. The rest of us will be out on the dance floor and soaking in the silky sass.

Advertising

43. â€˜Blinding Lightsâ€™ by The Weeknd

The Weeknd has been a pop heavyweight since he dropped his coke-fuelled banger â€˜Can't Feel My Faceâ€™ in 2015. But the Canadian superstar took things to another level with â€˜Blinding Lightsâ€™, a synth-driven monster that somehow managed to brighten up the summer of Covid, blasting out of cars everywhere as people escaped their bubbles. More than a year later, its power has only grown.

44. â€˜Crazyâ€™ by Gnarls Barkley

Long before his vile worldview and accusations of abuse made it all to easy to say â€˜Fu*k Youâ€™ to Cee-Lo Green, the former Goodie Mob emcee joined forces with producer Danger Mouse to release this slick psychedelic soul curveball. Fifteen years later, it still feels gloriously alien.

Advertising

45. â€˜Clint Eastwoodâ€™ by Gorillaz

Blur were always the most inventive of the Britpop bands. But in 1994 or so nobody would have reasonably expected that within a decade band leader Damon Albarn would have reinvented himself as frontman of a kaleidoscopic, no boundaries cartoon pop band called Gorillaz, nor that said cartoon pop band would genuinely go on to become bigger than Blur. Itâ€™s a tough contest, but their debut single â€˜Clint Eastwoodâ€™ perhaps remains their finest moment, an eerily loping slice of spaghetti western-tinged hip-pop, with a killer rap from Del the Funky Homosapien.
